name: Angular
description: together with React and Vue.js one of the three most popular JavaScript frameworks

name: CI/CD
description: the combined practices of continuous integration (CI) and continuous deployment (CD)

name: React
description: currently the most popular front-end JavaScript framework along with Vue and Angular

name: Swagger
description: a suite of tools for API developers created in 2011

name: REST
description: a way to make services on a web available to software and other websites

name: GitLab
description: a popular tool to organize the lifecyle of software development - a local GitHub

name: UX
description: how a user interacts with and experiences a software application including the person's perceptions of utility, ease of use, and efficiency

name: Testing
description: 1. unit tests, 2. integration tests, 3. end-to-end tests

name: Bootstrap
description: a ubiquitous CSS framework that simplifies website design

name: styled-components
description: the best bits of ES6 and CSS to style your React app components without stress

name: Storybook
description: a tool for UI development that makes development faster and easier by isolating components

name: FuseBox
description: module bundler that is simple to configure but has enough features to be a valid alternative to WebPack

name: Jasmine
description: an open-source testing framework for JavaScript

name: Hotjar
description: a software tool to track users

name: Piwik
description: a tool to track a customer's behavior across websites and apps

name: TypeScript
description: in larger applications, the preferred way to program in JavaScript

name: Jest
description: a JavaScript testing framework like Mocha, but simpler

name: Git
description: the most-used revision control system today

name: Next.js
description: a React framework that enables server-side rendering

name: NestJS
description: a Node.js framework for building efficient, reliable and scalable server-side applications

name: Responsive web design
description: an approach to web design that aims to make web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes from minimum to maximum display size to ensure usability and satisfaction

name: PWA
description: Progressive Web App - application software delivered through the web

name: HTML
description: the markup language that serves as the basis of websites

name: CSS
description: the language used to style websites and a standard tool for web development

name: JavaScript
description: the main scripting language of the Web

name: Mocha
description: one of the most popular JavaScript testing frameworks

name: Vue.js
description: can easily be used to enhance existing applications as well as to create new applications

name: MVC
description: an architectural pattern commonly used particularly in web development

name: C
description: low-level language used to program everything from hardware devices to operating systems

name: C++
description: low-level language for writing applications

name: Java
description: a popular and ubiquitious OOP programming language

name: C#
description: the standard OOP language on the .NET platform

name: MVVM
description: a pattern like MVC but with a View Model, gave rise to JavaScript frameworks

name: Azure
description: a cloud computing service created by Microsoft for building, testing, deploying, and managing applications and services

name: AWS
description: a subsidiary of Amazon that provides on-demand cloud computing platforms

name: GCP
description: a suite of cloud computing services that runs on the same infrastructure that Google uses internally for its end-user products, such as Google Search, Gmail and YouTube

name: SQL
description: the standard language you use to get data from relational databases

name: NoSQL
description: a type of non-table database used with big data

name: SAP
description: a German software company and world's leading enterprise resource planning (ERP) software vendor

name: XML
description: markup language for defining and transmitting data and documents

name: JSON
description: a popular standard for storing and transmitting information and data objects, particularly in JavaScript

name: Agile
description: a philosophy of software developer which includes adaptive planning, evolutionary development, early delivery, continual improvement, and flexible responses to changes in requirements, capacity, and understanding of the problems to be solved

name: scrum
description: a framework for project management designed for teams of ten or fewer members who break their work into goals that can be completed within time-boxed iterations, called sprints, no longer than one month and most commonly two weeks

name: Gitflow
description: a branching and merging methodology popularized by the blog post "A Successful Git branching model", older, seems overly complicated and controversial

name: Domain-Driven Design
description: a software design approach focused on modeling software to match a domain according to input from that domain's experts

name: microservices
description: an architectural pattern that arranges an application as a collection of loosely-coupled, fine-grained services, communicating through lightweight protocols, one goal being that teams can develop and deploy their services independently of others

name: .NET
description: the main Windows development framework since 2001

name: Entity Framework
description: object-relational mapping (ORM) framework for .NET

name: Hangfire
description: easy way to perform background processing in .NET and .NET Core applications

name: RabbitMQ
description: message-broker software that originally implemented AMQP

name: MUI
description: Material UI - React components for faster and easier web development

name: GraphQL
description: a newer and more robust alternative to REST

name: Apollo
description: the most popular GraphQL client

name: ASP.NET
description: the Microsoft .NET standard approach for developing websites

name: Docker
description: a software virtualization solution that allows each application to run in a separate container

name: Kubernetes
description: platform used for large-scale application automation including Docker

name: OpenShift
description: a family of containerization software products developed by Red Hat, similar to Kubernetes

name: NUnit
description: an open-source unit testing framework for the .NET Framework and Mono

name: Rider
description: a cross-platform IDE for .NET by JetBrains

name: DevOps Server
description: an Azure tool to share code, track work, and ship software using integrated software delivery tools, hosted on-premises

name: MongoDB
description: the most popular NoSQL document store database

name: cloud computing
description: on-demand and scalable availability of computer system resources, usually AWS, Azure or Google Cloud Platform

name: Kotlin
description: Google's new Java language

name: Swift
description: Apple's general-purpose, multi-paradigm, compiled programming language, developed as a replacement for Apple's earlier programming language Objective-C

name: Jetpack Compose
description: Android's recommended modern toolkit for building native UI

name: Firebase
description: a platform developed by Google for creating mobile and web applications

name: Flutter
description: Google's software development kit for mobile apps

name: Dart
description: a Google replacement for JavaScript which transpiles to JavaScript

name: Node
description: central JavaScript technology for web backend and application development

name: Express
description: a web application framework for Node.js and the de facto Node standard for building web applications and APIs

name: Magento
description: an e-commerce PHP framework created in 2008, now owned by Adobe

name: JQuery
description: a useful and popular but older JavaScript library

name: PHP
description: a popular and pragmatic programming language for websites

name: MySQL
description: a popular and widespread database for websites and applications

name: Apache
description: a old, classic and popular web server from the 90s

name: nginx
description: a fast web server that can also be used as a reverse proxy, load balancer, mail proxy and HTTP cache

name: Webpack
description: the most popular JavaScript module bundler

name: WebStorm
description: an integrated development environment for JavaScript and related technologies

name: Rollup
description: the second most popular module bundler for JavaScript

name: MINT
description: Bezeichnung von und Studienfächern aus den Bereichen Mathematik, Informatik, Naturwissenschaft und Technik, auf Englisch STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics)

name: machine learning
description: a part of artificial intelligence, ML algorithms build a model based on sample data, known as training data, in order to make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed to do so

name: Python
description: an older but pragmatic language and increasingly popular today used widely by scientists and mathematicians

name: Python Science Stack
description: a set of libraries for scientific computation and visualization including Python, NumPy, SciPy, matplotlib, IPython, pandas, SymPy and Jupyter Notebook

name: scikit-learn
description: a set of simple and efficient tools for predictive data analysis built on NumPy, SciPy and matplotlib

name: OOP
description: (Object-Oriented Programming) a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects, which can contain data and code, the data is in the form of properties and the code is in the form of methods, contrast with functional programming

name: Tensorflow
description: Google Brain's second-generation system focus on training and inference of deep neural networks

name: PyTorch
description: a machine learning framework based on the Torch library, used for applications such as computer vision and natural language processing

name: code review
description: the act of consciously and systematically convening with one’s fellow programmers to check each other’s code for mistakes and has been repeatedly shown to accelerate and streamline the process of software development

name: pair programming
description: technique in which two programmers work together at one workstation

name: Spring Boot
description: a tool that makes it easy to create stand-alone, production-grade Spring-based Applications for the Java platform

name: Serverless Computing
description: a misnomer in the sense that servers are still used by cloud service providers to execute code for developers, however, developers of serverless applications are not concerned with capacity planning, configuration, management, maintenance, fault tolerance, or scaling of containers, VMs, or physical servers

name: CQRS
description: (Command Query Responsibility Singleton) the notion that you can use a different model to update information than the model you use to read information

name: microfrontends
description: what you get when you bring the microservice approach to the frontend, a frontend made of components owned by different teams that can be deployed independently

name: Tailwind
description: a highly customizable, low-level, low-opinionated CSS framework

name: GitHub Actions
description: a continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) platform that allows you to automate your build, test, and deployment pipeline

name: Fluent UI
description: a Microsoft collection of UX frameworks for creating cross-platform apps

name: TypeORM
description: an ORM that can be run with TypeScript, connect multiple databases, and can run in NodeJS, Browser, Cordova, PhoneGap, Ionic, React Native, NativeScript, Expo, and Electron platforms

name: PostgreSQL
description: a robust but less popular SQL database than MySQL

name: Redis
description: the most popular key-value database

name: ZenHub
description: an agile project management tool designed to help software teams organize, plan, track, and manage their work, available either inside GitHub via a browser extension or as a standalone web app

name: Ionic Appflow
description: a CI/CD platform for Ionic development teams that helps development teams continuously build and ship their Cordova, Capacitor, and React Native apps

name: AWS Lambda
description: Amazon's event-driven, serverless cloud platform

name: Salesforce
description: a cloud-based software company which provides customer relationship management (CRM) software and applications focused on sales, customer service, marketing automation, analytics, and application development

name: Microsoft Dynamics
description: a collection of 12 applications used for enterprise resource planning (ERP) and customer relationship management (CRM) for intelligent business applications, announced by Microsoft in July 2016

name: GitHub
description: the standard platform to store, publish, and share code projects on the web

name: DevOps
description: set of practices that combines software development and IT operations which aims to shorten the systems development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality

name: clean code
description: a set of coding principles which include: follow conventions, keep it simple, leave code cleaner than when you found it, always find the root cause

name: Cypress
description: a testing tool that automates and scales end-to-end testing

name: Open API
description: an API that is open for use by developers with relatively few restrictions, typically without copyright restrictions

name: Redux
description: JavaScript library for maintaining state, used with React and Angular

name: Sass
description: a preprocessor scripting language that is interpreted or compiled into Cascading Style Sheets

name: Jira
description: popular bug and issue-tracking software

name: Confluence
description: a web-based corporate wiki

name: Jenkins
description: an older but popular build automation tool still used in many companies

name: SSR
description: in contrast to client-side rendering, server-side rendering generates static content on the server before sending it over to the user's browser, which better addresses performance and search engine optimization issues of single-page JavaScript applications

name: Remix
description: a React framework used for server-side rendering (SSR) and unlike Next.js, it enables nested routing with nested layouts

name: Chakra UI
description: a simple, modular and accessible component library that gives you the building blocks you need to build your React applications

name: React Native
description: a popular JavaScript framework for building mobile apps

name: LiveKit
description: an open source WebRTC project that gives you everything needed to build scalable and real-time audio, video, and data experiences in applications

name: Socket.IO
description: JavaScript library that enables realtime, bi-directional communication between web clients and servers

name: Terraform
description: infrastructure as code software tool created by HashiCorp

name: Nx
description: a build-system tool to develop multiple full-stack applications that share code between them all in the same workspace

name: Babel
description: a JavaScript transpiler which enables you to use higher versions of ECMAScript

name: CircleCI
description: a continuous integration platform that helps ship software faster, using code that's reusable and easy to maintain

name: React Testing Library
description: a light-weight solution for testing React components

name: TestCafe
description: an end-to-end testing framework for web applications that runs on Node

name: SuperTest
description: provides a high-level abstraction for testing HTTP and APIs

name: Piral
description: a framework to build portal applications that follow the microfrontends architecture

name: Hetzner Cloud
description: a Germany cloud provider which operates data center parks in Germany, Finland and the USA

name: InfluxDB
description: a time-series database (for time-stampted event data) written in Go and used for storage of e.g. Internet of Things senso data and real-time analytics

name: AI
description: software that enables itself to learn within a specific context in order to process data to solve tasks that otherwise require human intelligence

name: React Hooks
description: Hooks are a new addition in React 16.8, they let you use state and other React features without writing a class.

name: Polymer
description: a JavaScript framework created and used by Google which embraces the Material Design ideology

name: Stencil
description: a compiler that generates web components which use TypeScript, JSX, and CSS

name: Vite
description: a tool to set up development starter applications for frameworks like Vue, React, Svelte and JS/DOM

name: A/B tests
description: the process of comparing two variations of a page element, usually by testing users' response to variant A vs. variant B and concluding which of the two variants is more effective

name: Gradle
description: a build automation tool for multi-language software development that controls the development process from compilation and packaging to testing, deployment, and publishing, supported languages include Java, Kotlin, Groovy, Scala, C/C++, and JavaScript

name: D3.js
description: a JavaScript library for manipulating documents based on data

name: Projektron BCS
description: web-based project management software for planning, managing and controlling projects simultaneously, founded 2001 in Berlin

name: Svelte
description: JavaScript framework that generates code to manipulate the DOM

name: Tomcat
description: a free and open-source Java web application server

name: JBoss
description: a free and open-source Java application server developed by Red Hat that implements the Java Enterprise Edition specification, today known as WildFly

name: MQTT
description: a lightweight, publish-subscribe, machine to machine network protocol for Message queue/Message queuing service

name: AMQP
description: an open standard application layer protocol for message-oriented middleware responsible for orientation, queuing, and has both point-to-point  and publish-and-subscribe routing

name: Maven
description: a build automation tool used primarily for Java projects which can also be used to build and manage projects written in C#, Ruby, and Scala

name: MariaDB
description: a community-developed, commercially supported fork of MySQL

name: Gitlab CI
description: an feature of GitLab which provides build automation, test automation, pipeline config management, artifact storage, and pipeline security

name: FastAPI
description: a modern, fast, web framework for building APIs with Python

name: Go
description: a language created by Google that resembles C but with object-oriented features

name: EKS
description: AWS's container platform (Elastic Kubernetes Service)

name: Python/Qt
description: a Python library that enables developers to use Python to write Qt applications
